resources.string: Possessive Case ( \'s )
Possessive Case

The possessive case shows ownership. With the addition of 's (or sometimes just the apostrophe), a noun can change from a simple person, place, or thing to a person, place, or thing that owns something. There are a few different ways to form the possessive of a noun. 

 The ending –'s 
	The ending -'s is added to singular nouns and names.
This is my car and this is Jack\'s car
Work for men -> men’s work
Apostrophe «’» \n\n\tIf the word already ends with “s”, often in plural words, then we use only the apostrophe «’» without “s”
The boys’ toys
The dogs’ cages are small
With things: of \n\n\tFor objects you cannot use "-\'s", we use "of"
income of the company
rules of the game
Reflexive Pronouns\n(myself, yourself)
Reflexive Pronouns

\tA reflexive pronoun is a specific type of pronoun that is used for the object of a verb when it refers to the same noun as the subject of that verb. In English, these are the pronouns that end with “-self” or “-selves”: e.g., “himself,” “myself,” “ourselves,” etc.
I asked myself.
I cut myself while cooking.
You should take care of yourself.
\tHow is it formed:

Singular 
I -> me -> myself 
you -> you -> yourself 
he -> him -> himself 
she -> her -> herself 
it -> it -> itself 

Plural 
we -> us -> ourselves 
you -> you -> yourselves 
they -> them -> themselves

Exceptions \n\nThere are some words that are not used with reflexive pronouns, even though they are self-directed. These are verbs indicating actions that people usually do themselves: wash, shave, dress, feel, and others.
I feel bad today.
I dressed quickly.
Degree of Comparison\n(big -> bigger -> biggest)
Degree of Comparison
Mark is fast but Bob is faster.
\tEvery adjective and adverb can be written in one of three degrees: The Positive Degree, The Comparative Degree, The Superlative Degree:
warm - warmer - warmest
hot - hotter - hottest
simple - simpler - simplest
happy - happier - happiest

string.i: Adjectives of three or more syllables

resources.string: modern - more modern - most modern
terrible - more terrible - most terrible
\tMonosyllabic adjectives (One syllable adjectives) - add -er for the comparative and -est for the superlative.
big - bigger - the biggest

\tDisyllabic adjectives - adjectives with two syllables can form the comparative either by adding -er or by preceding the adjective with more. These adjectives form the superlative either by adding -est or by preceding the adjective with most. In many cases, both forms are used.
crazy - crazier - the craziest
crazy - more crazy - the most crazy

\tAdjectives with three or more syllables form the comparative by putting more in front of the adjective, and the superlative by putting most in front. \n\n\tThese very common adjectives have completely irregular comparative and superlative forms:
Let’s go to practice!
The Imperative Mood\n(Come to me!)
The Imperative Mood
\tThe Imperative Mood is the form of the verb that makes direct commands and requests:
Come to me!
\tThe imperative mood uses the bare infinitive form, without "to".
Relax! Listen! Hide!
\tThe negative is formed simply by adding Don’t:
Don’t lie!
Don’t answer!
\tIn order to express motivation in relation to a third person, you need to use the verb let:
Let her speak!
Let them go!
\tMore than an imperative, this imperative is an exhortation and only applies to the first-person plural(we). It is formed using Let + us = Let’s
Let\'s go to the cinema
Let\'s buy ice-cream
Present Perfect
Present Perfect

We use the Present Perfect: 

1. for something that started in the past and continues in the present 
2. when we are talking about our experience up to the present 
3. for something that happened in the past but is important in the present
I have already done my homework.

Present Perfect is formed with the help of the auxiliary verb have or has and the verb in form 3 (Past Participle). 

	What is the 3rd form of the verb? 
All verbs in English have 3 forms, 1 form is a verb without changes (infinitive), 2 and 3 forms for regular verbs are formed only by adding –ed as in Past Simple. But there are irregular verbs that have no rules. They just need to be memorized.
do -> did -> done \nspeak -> spoke -> spoken \nfind -> found -> found
\tHow is it formed
\tUsing the Present Perfect \n\n\tPresent Perfect is used only when we do not tell the exact time! Present Perfect is often used with words like already, recently, just, ever, never.
I have already done this job.
We have just got back from our holidays.
\tImportant! \n\n\tIf we use the past time of action, then this is no longer Present Perfect, but Past Simple (A1 topic 7).
I did this job well yesterday.
Conjunctions II\n(for, since, while …)
Conjunctions II
\tThis is the second part of the ‘Conjunctions’ topic (A1 topic 12). In this topic, we will look at a few more conjunctions:

Subordinate conjunctions: 

as – because, for the reason that 
for – because, as, for the reason that 
since – because, as, for
As I am tired I don’t go to shopping
Jane went away for she felt bad
I can’t call him since I don’t know his number

Conjunctions of time: 

while – during the time that, or at the same time as 
since – from a particular time in the past until a later time, or until now 
until(till) – up to (the time that)
She was thinking about him while she was reading
She has been travelling since she divorced
I will not do it until you tell me

Condition conjunctions: 

unless – what will or will not happen if something else does not happen or is not true 
in case – if something happens
You can\'t get a job unless you have experience
Take an umbrella in case it rains.
Modal Verbs II\n(need, have to, be able to)
Modal Verbs II
\tAt A1 level, we learned the modal verbs can, must, may, should. In this topic, we will learn need, have to, be able to.
\thave (got) to – use in the past, present, and future to express responsibility or necessity. We often use have to to say that something is obligatory, for example:
I have to work
He has to work
I had to work
I will have to work
\tThe negative form is formed with do (don\'t, doesn\'t) like regular verbs.
We don’t have to work

\tWe use be able to to express ability. "Able" is an adjective meaning: having the power, skill or means to do something. If we say "I am able to swim", it is like saying "I can swim". We sometimes use be able to instead of "can" or "could" for ability. Be able to is possible in all tenses - but "can" is possible only in the present and "could" is possible only in the past for ability.
I will be able to play football tomorrow
I’m able to play the guitar
I was able to do it

\tNeed is a semi-modal verb because in some ways it is like a modal verb and in other ways like a main verb.\n We use need mostly in the negative form to indicate that there is no obligation or necessity to do something:
You needn’t do this
\tWe often use the main verb need as an alternative to semi-modal need. Main verb need is followed by to and it changes with person, number and tense:
They need to go home.
She needs to clean the room.
Do you need it?
I needed your help yesterday.
Prepositions of Place\n(inside, under, near…)
Prepositions of Place
\tPrepositions of Place are used to indicate where an object/person is located or where an action takes place.
1. in, inside – in or into a room, building, container, or something similar
The cat is in the box
2. under, below – lower than (or covered by) something else
The cat hid under the bed
3. on – used to show that something is in a position above something else and touching it
The glass is on the table
4. above – higher than something else, but not directly over it
There\'s a mirror above the sink
5. near, by, next to – not far away in distance
I live near Moscow
6. behind – at the back (of)
I\'m behind the house
7. between – in or into the space which separates two places, people or objects
On the plane I was sitting between two large men
8. around – in a position or direction surrounding, or in a direction going along the edge of or from one part to another (of)
We sat around the table
9. among – in the middle of or surrounded by other things
She feel lonely among all these people
Prepositions of Movement\n(up, down, over…)
Prepositions of Movement
\tPrepositions of Movement indicate the direction of the action, its starting or ending points.
1. up – movement from a lower point to a higher point
The rocket flies up
2. down – movement from a higher point to a lower point
Is this elevator going down?
3. over – movement above and across the top or top surface of something
The dog jumped over the fence
4. into – movement to an enclosed space
He scored the ball into the goal!
5. off / out of – movement away from
My wallet fell out of my pocket
6. towards – movement in the direction of something
She walked towards him
7. along – in a line next to something long
I\'m driving along the road
8. across – movement from one side to the other side of something
We sat around the table
9. through – movement in one side and out of the other side of something
We will drive through the tunnel
Prepositions of Time\n(by, for, since …)
Prepositions of Time

\tPrepositions of Time indicate the time of the action, its duration, or a specific period of time. \n\tAt A1 level, we learned in, on, at. In this topic, we will learn: since, for, within, till, until, by, after, before
1. since – from a particular time in the past until a later time, or until now
I have been living in New York since 2018
2. for – used to show an amount of time
I have been living in New York for 4 years
3. within – inside or not further than a period of time
They should arrive within three days
4. till, until – up to the stated time
I work from 7 am until 6 pm
5. by – not later than; at or before
I will be there by 7
6. after – following in time
The train doesn’t arrive after 9 o\'clock
7. before – at or during a time earlier than
Everybody is nervous before exams
Past Continuous
Past Continuous
Yesterday I was learning English

\tThe Past Continuous tense, also known as the Past Progressive tense, refers to a continuing action or state that was happening at some point in the past. \n\n\tThe past continuous tense is formed by combining the past tense of to be (was/were) with the verb’s present participle (-ing word).
I was working from 4 to 6 o\'clock
She was cleaning the house when the phone rang
When was she doing her homework?
\tThe Past Continuous often is used with while, when
While I was eating my soup, she came home
I worked while you were sleeping
Constructions - used to /\nto be used to
used to
\tUsed to is a verb we use to talk about something that happened in the past that doesn’t happen anymore. We always use it in the past tense.
I used to get up at 6 am when I was 7
Kate used to go to school by bike
\tThe negative sentence is formed with the auxiliary verb did + not followed by use to
She didn’t use to ride a bike
We didn’t use to go to Italy every summer
\tThe interrogative sentence:
Did you use to ride a bike?
Did he use to do sports?
Choose “be used to” to say you are accustomed to something, and so it seems normal or usual. If you are used to something, it is not difficult, new or strange.
I’m used to working on Saturday
He is used to the cold weather
I’ll never be used to living in a city
The Gerund (-ing)
The Gerund
\tGerund - an English noun formed from a verb by adding -ing \n\n\tFor example, the verb to eat becomes the noun eating
Eating hamburgers is not good for you
\tThe verb to smoke -> smoking
Smoking can destroy your health
\tThe particle no or not is placed before the noun.
No playing and no talking after 10 pm!
\tThese nouns are not used with the articles (the, a / an)
Adverbs of Frequency\n(always, often, never…)
Adverbs of Frequency
\tAdverbs of Frequency describe how often an action happens. There are 7 main adverbs of frequency that we use in English:

always - 100% 
usually - 90% 
often - 70% 
sometimes - 50% 
seldom - 20% 
rarely - 10% 
never - 0%
You always help me
I usually get up at 7 a.m.
We often go to this restaurant
Sometimes I eat fast food
I seldom drive into the city
I rarely have time to read the news
I have never been to London
The Verb “would”
Would

\tWould is the past tense form of will. Because it is a past tense, it is used to talk about the future in the past, to talk about hypotheses, for politeness. Next, we will learn more about how would is used
\t1. Requests and suggestions\n\n Used in requests or suggestions, for politeness. Often would is used with like and it means “to want”.
Would you like some tea or coffee?
I would like to ask you a question
would often can be shorten to just one letter \'d
I’d like to ask you a question
\t2. Future in the Past\n\n When talking about the past we can use would to express something that has not happened at the time we are talking about:
He said he would come early
She asked if I would help her
I thought you would come
\t3. To express a strong desire to refuse to perform an action
Не wouldn\'t go to the doctor
\t4. Would = Used to\n\n Would can replace used to, which is used to describe habitual, repetitive actions in the past that are no longer repeated in the present.
We used to go to the park on weekends
We would go to the park on weekends
Phrasal Verbs\n(put on, take off, look for)
Phrasal Verbs

\tPhrasal verbs are very common in English, especially in more informal contexts. They are made up of a verb and a particle or, sometimes, two particles. The particle often changes the meaning of the verb. \n\n\tHere are some important phrasal verbs:
look for – to search for someone or something
I\'m looking for a new apartment
look after – to take care of someone or something
He looks after his son
look like – to be similar in appearance to someone or something
He looks like his father
put on – start wearing something
I put on my jacket
take off – to remove clothing
I took off my jacket
try on – to put on a piece of clothing in order to see how it looks
Can I try on the jacket?
turn on/off - make something start/stop working
Turn on the music!
come back - return
I’ll come back
wake up – to become conscious after sleeping
I just woke up
fall asleep – to start to sleep
I\'m falling asleep
keep on – to start to sleep
I decided to keep on at my job
Irregular Verbs\n(know -> knew -> known)
Irregular Verbs

Irregular verbs are those that have a special form for Past Simple and Past Participle (which is needed for tenses like Present Perfect). 

	These verbs have no rules, just need to be remembered: 

begin - began - begun
I begin work at 7 o\'clock
Yesterday I began reading a book
Peter has not begun reading yet
I should buy a new car
I bought a new car yesterday
I have never bought a car
I can drive a car
I drove to town last week
I have never driven a car
I know you
I knew this would happen
They have known each other for years
